required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Determining the Lymphokine Activated Killer (LAK) Cytotoxicity Present in Patients Undergoing Interleukin-2 Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Lymphokine Activated Killer (LAK) Cell Activity Against Cell Lines In-vitro of LAK Generated in Vivo by Pulse Interleukin-2 Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: Therapy with Interleukin-2 stimulates lymphocytes in humans to become Lymphokine-activated Killer cells (LAK). This study will determine if these killer cells are able to kill certain standard cell-lines in the laboratory.

detailed_description.textblock: Blood samples will be taken from patients undergoing outpatient Interleukin-2 therapy to measure the LAK cytotoxicity at baseline, after 1 cycle of therapy and 2 months later. The LAK cytotoxicity assay will be a standard colorimetric assay that measures lactic dehydrogenase release from lysed cells.

arm_group.arm_group_label: patients with melanoma or kidney cancer

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing Interleukin-2 therapy under the care of physicians at Loma Linda University Cancer Center

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients must be undergoing Interleukin-2 therapy under the care of physicians at Loma Linda University Cancer Center
- Patients must sign and give written informed consent in accordance with institutional and federal guidelines
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients not undergoing Interleukin-2 therapy under the care of physicians at Loma Linda University Cancer Center
